data.name: Roles and Permissions
data.description:
You are tasked with setting up a role and permissions system. The system contains two basic objects, a `Role` and a `Permission`. 

A `Permission` represents something that a user can do, such as *use a printer* or *add a new user*.

A `Role` represents a group of permissions and **can have many other roles**. If a role has another role, then it will inherit its permissions from the other role.

Your job is to implement the `Role#all_permissions` method, which returns an array of unique permissions.

## Considerations

* Ordering does not matter
* The `#all_permissions` method may be called multiple times on a single object
* It is possible for roles and permissions to be poorly configured:
   * A role can reference itself
   * A permission can be used in more than one role

## Examples
A basic example would look something like this:

```ruby
# Set up basic permissions
log_in        = Permission.new "Log in to the system"
open_programs = Permission.new "Open basic programs"
use_printer   = Permission.new "Use Printer"
use_usb       = Permission.new "Use USB Drive"

# Roles
basic_user = Role.new "Basic User"
basic_user.permissions = [open_programs, log_in]

# prints "Log in to the system, Open basic programs"
puts basic_user.all_permissions.map(&:name).join(', ') 

elevated_user = Role.new "Elevated user"
elevated_user.roles       = [basic_user]
elevated_user.permissions = [use_usb, use_printer]

# prints "Log in to the system, Open basic programs, Use USB Drive, Use Printer"
puts elevated_user.all_permissions.map(&:name).join(', ') 
```

However, it is possible for roles and permissions to be configured poorly: 

```ruby
basic_user.roles << elevated_user  # Cycle!
basic_user.permissions << use_usb  # Duplicate permission
```

Regardless of how they are configured, the output should still be sane:

```ruby
# now prints for a basic user "Log in to the system, Open basic programs, Use USB Drive, Use Printer
puts basic_user.all_permissions.map(&:name).join(', ') 
```

## Permission Class
The Permission class is already provided for you
```ruby
class Permission
  attr_reader :name
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
end
```
